image.altText: ASIC sign

props.synopsis: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, isn't prosecuting enough white-collar crime and can't perform its full range of duties, so a Senate committee has recommended it split into two new, more streamlined regulators.

title.children: Senate committee recommends major overhaul for corporate watchdog, splitting ASIC into two new regulators

image.altText: A person holds a bag of nitazenes powder.

props.synopsis: There are fears of more overdoses as nitazenes infiltrate Australia's underground drug supply, with occasional recreational drug users warned the synthetic opioid is being found in drugs like cocaine.

title.children: Nitazenes are coming into Australia from India and China. Their effects are deadly

image.altText: Joe Biden with one hand raised partially covered by dark shadows.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden has jet lag. Joe Biden has a cold. Joe Biden was over-prepared. Joe Biden was under-prepared. Joe Biden has a stutter. Defenders of the president have trotted out plenty of excuses since last week's catastrophic first debate against Donald Trump. But should they replace him?

title.children: Should Joe Biden step down? Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson and Jimmy Carter have a warning

image.altText: A middle aged woman wearing glasses in a dark room looks sternly at the camera.

props.synopsis: Farah Priela, a California school teacher, was exploring Queensland's north coast when she boarded the Greyhound service to begin her journey back to America.

title.children: 'This might be my last day': Passenger in fatal bus crash shares terrifying moments before collision

image.altText: A house with police tape around it

props.synopsis: Victoria Police's Homicide Squad is investigating the death of the 27-year-old man, who officers say became unwell and unresponsive while they were arresting him.

title.children: Five police officers taken to hospital after Macedon Ranges man dies during arrest

image.altText: Iris Smit, Inventor of The Quick Flick

props.synopsis: Small beauty entrepreneurs say they are struggling to stop copies of their cosmetics being released because they don't have the legal budgets to fight big companies that are self-confessed dupers.

title.children: 'Is this really ethical?' Iris sees her product being copied weekly, but she can't afford to do anything about it

image.altText: A close-up shot of a shopping trolley full of groceries in a supermarket with a woman behind bagging apples.

props.synopsis: Spending is down, but there are two sectors Australians are still willing to fork out money for.

title.children: Australians are reining in their spending across the board — except when it comes to these two things

image.altText: A group of Japanese citizens holding up banners in celebration after a court ruling

props.synopsis: A post-war eugenics law passed in Japan to "prevent birth of inferior descendants" was found in violation of the constitution by the country's top court, with victim-survivors being handed a major win after years of seeking justice.

title.children: Japan's supreme court upholds case brought by victims of forced sterilisation against government

image.altText: A white balloon attached via to a white bag of trash sits on a river.

props.synopsis: Seoul MP Jeong Jun-ho says the trash-filled balloons which North Korea sent over the border to South Korea affected thousands of travel plans.

title.children: Trash-filled balloons sent from North Korea affected over 10,000 South Korea plane passengers, Seoul MP says

image.altText: Three men in suits, looking serious.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's plan to force large supermarkets to sell stores has prompted a fierce internal debate, with some objecting to the potential cost of court cases.

title.children: Dutton's supermarket push leaves some colleagues feeling 'ambushed'

image.altText: A phone screen displays Booktopia's green and white app with a search bar visible

props.synopsis: The Australian online bookstore has announced it has appointed administrators to possibly restructure or sell the business after a year of losses.

title.children: Australian online bookseller Booktopia in freefall as administrators called in

image.altText: Vision from a helicopter zeroing in on the gorilla statue hidden between two containers.

props.synopsis: Garry the gorilla will be returned to his rightful home at a Victorian retirement village after the fibreglass silverback was stolen last month.

title.children: After vanishing in broad daylight, Victoria Police have located Garry the gorilla

image.altText: A close up of RFK Jr's face

props.synopsis: Independent US presidential candidate Robert F Kennedy Jr says he has "so many skeletons in my closet," following an allegation in a Vanity Fair article that he sexually assaulted a former family babysitter.

title.children: Robert F Kennedy Junior says he has 'skeletons in my closet' after sexual assault allegation

image.altText: Jade Young, 47, was fatally stabbed at Westfield Bondi Junction on Saturday, April 13, 2024

props.synopsis: The mother of Jade Young, who was killed in April's Bondi Junction stabbing, is asking state, territory and federal governments to better coordinate their responses to complex mental health needs.

title.children: 'Mental health system is in crisis': Family of Bondi Junction stabbing victim say they struggled to get vital support

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks across the table at Peter Dutton during Question Time.

props.synopsis: This seems as good a time as any to evaluate the reliability of what politicians tell us about the housing crisis — and how they're going to make things better.

title.children: 'Build more houses' sure sounds great as a solution to the housing crisis, but a few key factors scream 'buyer beware'

image.altText: Members of the Australian women's rugby sevens team pose for a photo holding large boarding passes.

props.synopsis: The Australian women's rugby sevens team is one of the gold medal favourites for the Paris Olympics, and that suits them just fine according to coach Tim Walsh because "if you're expected to win, it means you've been winning".

title.children: 'No regret': The motto driving the Australian women's rugby sevens team's quest for Paris gold

image.altText: A visualisation of a computer drawing of a face dissolving.

props.synopsis: The privacy of Australian children is being violated on a large scale, with their personal images — and sometimes their names and locations — being used to train the AI powering most of the world's image-generators.

title.children: The world's biggest AI models were trained using images of Australian kids, and their families had no idea

image.altText: Stephen Pokrywka in a flannel shirt, holding his young grandchildren

props.synopsis: An Australian resident of more than four decades is deported to the United Kingdom after his visa was cancelled due to a drug conviction, with a last-minute appeal rejected by the Federal Court.

title.children: Stephen Pokrywka has been deported, and wasn't allowed to see his Australian family in person before he left

image.altText: A row of pods inside a trailer.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian homelessness charity has removed two mobile trailers containing sleeping pods for people sleeping rough after being told it didn't have permission to put them there, in the latest tussle with the local council.

title.children: Charity told to remove homeless sleeping pods set up without council permit in latest tussle

image.altText: A swampy shallow creek with trees around

props.synopsis: A police search will continue throughout the night for a missing 12-year-old child reportedly attacked by a crocodile near the remote Northern Territory community of Palumpa, 360 kilometres south-west of Darwin.

title.children: Search for missing child, reportedly attacked by crocodile, to continue tonight in remote NT

image.altText: A composite image of Ariana Grande as Glinda in Wicked, and Paul Mescal in Gladiator 2

props.synopsis: Wicked, the highly anticipated screen adaption of the Broadway musical, will now be released on the same day as Ridley Scott's Gladiator 2, setting the stage for a box office showdown similar to Barbenheimer.

title.children: Barbenheimer 2.0: Will Wicked and Gladiator 2 create another box office phenomenon?

image.altText: A woman wearing colourful clothes, sitting on an outdoors bench.

props.synopsis: Lisa Millar announces she is farewelling the News Breakfast couch after five years in the role, to focus on other projects across the ABC.

title.children: Lisa Millar to farewell ABC News Breakfast

image.altText: Two women walking next to each other on the street. They are wearing face masks and jackets

props.synopsis: COVID-19 continues to evolve at a fast pace, with the latest highly transmissible variant, nicknamed FLuQE emerging as the dominant strain in Australia and across parts of the world.

title.children: FLiRT was dominating COVID-19 cases, now we're already onto FLuQE

image.altText: CCTV of boy accused of University of Sydney student stabbing dressed in camouflage, person ahead and beside of him charged

props.synopsis: A 14-year-old boy has been arrested and is undergoing health assessments after he allegedly stabbed a 22-year-old student at the University of Sydney on Tuesday morning. The Counter Terrorism and and Special Tactics Command is investigating the stabbing.

title.children: 14yo boy accused of stabbing University of Sydney student in neck charged last year, police minister says

image.altText: Derek Bromley speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide man who has spent four decades in jail for a murder he maintains he never committed has been released on parole.

title.children: Derek Bromley released on parole after four decades behind bars for murder of Stephen Docoza

image.altText: Mugshot of a woman with blonde hair

props.synopsis: British neonatal nurse Lucy Letby has been found guilty of trying to kill another premature baby under her care at the Countess of Chester Hospital in 2016.

title.children: Serial killer nurse Lucy Letby convicted of attempting to murder baby girl

image.altText: Rudy Giuliani speaks to the press, wearing glasses and a suit, hand raised to chest level

props.synopsis: Rudolph Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, federal prosecutor and legal adviser to Donald Trump, is disbarred in New York, with a court finding he repeatedly made false statements about Trump's 2020 election loss.

title.children: Giuliani disbarred in New York as court finds he repeatedly lied about Trump's 2020 election loss

image.altText: A man in a suit wearing a blue tie standing next to a man in a suit with a red tie.

props.synopsis: If the polls are correct, the Conservative Party will be kicked out of power after 14 years.

title.children: Polls suggest Sir Keir Starmer will be Britain's next PM. But he won't be enthusiastically swept into power by the public

image.altText: A woman in her 20s smiles with an orange backdrop, wearing a black dress

props.synopsis: It's Pay Day! Author Elfy Scott answers all the money questions we don't like to talk about as we seek to demystify personal finance and normalise conversations about how we think about money, what we earn and how we spend it.

title.children: 'It makes me feel ill': Author Elfy Scott on the reality of living in Sydney's current rental market

image.altText: A girl with a pony tail, white top and jeans sits on a couch and looks out the window, she appears worried

props.synopsis: Charlie's 12-year-old daughter is so anxious that she bites her nails until they bleed. Here are some ways parents can help children in distress.

title.children: Kids are more anxious than ever. Here are some ways parents can help

image.altText: Woman with head in hands with tax return on screen in the background.

props.synopsis: About 14 million Australians will be prepping their tax returns in the coming weeks. But the ATO is warning taxpayers not to jump in too soon.

title.children: Thinking about lodging your tax return soon? Here's why you should wait

image.altText: Frost covers leaves.

props.synopsis: Residents across South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania woke up to freezing temperatures and frost this morning. The conditions have sent weather records tumbling across suburbs and towns across southern Australia.

title.children: Frosty weather sends minimum temperatures below zero across parts of southern Australia

image.altText: woman wearing a pink puffer jacket and peaking through the hood

props.synopsis: To keep your puffer jacket, ugg boots and Oodie looking good for many seasons to come, we've got some simple cleaning tips that don't involve a drycleaner.

title.children: How to clean puffer jackets, Oodies and ugg boots (and why you shouldn't wear socks with slippers)

image.altText: Waves crash into a sea wall after a hurricane makes landfall

props.synopsis: Beryl becomes the earliest category five hurricane on record on Tuesday, with bureaus warning of the catastrophic damage it could bring to Jamaica and the Cayman Islands in the next few days.

title.children: Hurricane Beryl becomes category five storm at record rate, prompting warnings of extreme danger
